titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Dorothy M. Horstmann Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Bella Berson

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 10:57

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers include include correspondence, writings, research data, notes, memorabilia, and photographs, which document Dorothy Horstmann's years at the Yale School of Medicine as a bio-medical researcher and teacher. The papers highlight her accomplishments in understanding and controlling the transmission of poliomyelitis and rubella.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Dorothy M. Horstmann, 1995-1996; gift of Arthur Ebbert, Jr., 2002.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: While this collection as a whole is available for research, parts of it may be restricted due to law, university policy or fragility. Any restricted material will be noted as such.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Dorothy M. Horstmann Papers (MS 1700). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: John Rodman Paul Papers (MS 1333), Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in seven series: I. General Files, 1927-1995. II. Writings, 1946-1994, n.d. III. Teaching, 1947-1983. IV. Research and Consultations, 1940-1990. V. Professional Meetings, 1951-1994. VI. Personal Papers, 1941-2001. VII. Photographs, 1940-1994.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Dorothy Horstmann Papers include correspondence, writings, research data, notes, memorabilia, and photographs, which document Dorothy Horstmann's years at the Yale School of Medicine as a bio-medical researcher and teacher. The papers highlight her accomplishments in the epidemiology and conquest of poliomyelitis and rubella.

Horstmann's work as a virologist studying polio and rubella is amply documented in her writings and in extensive research data. The papers also include notes and reports from her research trips to Russia, Poland, Czechoslovakia, China, and Korea. While the papers contain a scant quantity of material from Horstmann's classroom teaching, they do reflect her role as a mentor to other scientists. The papers also chronicle Horstmann's involvement in professional organizations and her love of travel.

The collection includes a large quantity of materials related to John Rodman Paul, which document Horstmann's close working relationship with her mentor. This material consists of correspondence between Paul and Horstmann and with others concerning their joint projects. Evidence of her collaboration on Paul's publications is apparent in the papers, especially on her work to ensure the publication of Paul's History of Poliomyelitis. Other Paul materials in this collection include files on the preparation of a 1961 festschrift in Paul's honor and letters of condolence at his death.

Noticeably missing from the papers are materials about Horstmann's childhood or early career, and though Horstmann's appointment to an endowed chair at the university was a first, her papers contain little personal reflection on the challenges of being a woman scientist.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Dorothy Millicent Horstmann was internationally known for her significant contributions to the understanding and control of poliomyelitis and congenital rubella. The many tributes and honors accorded her make clear how highly she was regarded as a researcher, clinician, teacher and friend.

Horstmann was born in Spokane, Washington, on July 2, 1911. After earning both her bachelors degree (1936) and her M.D. (1940) from the University of California, San Francisco and completing residencies at San Francisco County Hospital and at Vanderbilt University Hospital, she came to Yale University in 1942 as a post doctoral Commonwealth Fund fellow in the Section of Preventive Medicine of the School of Medicine. Here John Rodman Paul, director of the Yale Poliomyelitis Study Unit, stimulated her interest in the epidemiology and pathogenesis of viral infections. In 1944, she was appointed instructor in the Section of Preventive Medicine. She spent the year 1944/1945 as an instructor in the Department of Medicine at the University of California, San Francisco and 1947/1948 as a National Institutes of Health Fellow at the Institute of Medical Research in London. Otherwise, she served the entire remainder of her career as a faculty member at Yale. She became an assistant professor in 1948 and attained the rank of associate professorship in 1952. In 1961, she became the first woman to be appointed professor at the Yale School of Medicine. In 1969, when she became the John Rodman Paul Professor of Epidemiology and Public Health, she was the first woman ever to hold an endowed chair at the university. President Kingman Brewster appointed her to the Committee on the Status of Academic and Professional Women at Yale in 1970.

Horstmann's early research focused on the pathogenesis of the poliomyelitis virus. In 1946 she discovered that the virus is present in human blood during the incubation period of the infection but disappears later, when the neurologic symptoms begin. This research breakthrough implied that if serum antibodies could be induced by vaccination, the virus in the blood could be neutralized and thus prevent the virus from affecting the central nervous system. Demonstrated through carefully conceived experimental studies in monkeys and epidemiologically based human observations, this discovery became the basis for an efficacious vaccine against polio.

From 1955 to 1961, the Yale Poliomyelitis Unit evaluated immunization against poliomyelitis with live, attenuated vaccine, the Sabin vaccine. It carried out trials of both the Sabin and the Salk vaccines in New Haven, Guadalupe village in Arizona, Costa Rica, and also in Middletown and Southbury, Connecticut. Horstmann also evaluated the oral polio vaccine program in Russia, Czechoslovakia and Poland for the World Health Organization. The resulting report helped develop acceptance of the Sabin vaccine in the United States. In the 1960s and 1970s, Horstmann also did research on the clinical epidemiology of the rubella virus. Her work played a significant role in assuring the safety and effectiveness of rubella vaccine.

When John Rodman Paul died in 1971, leaving unfinished his History of Poliomyelitis, Horstmann took up the task of seeing this work through to publication and of producing a festschrift in his memory. In recognition of her scholarly contributions, Horstmann was elected to the National Academy of Science and the Royal Society of Medicine. In 1983, she chaired the Organizing Committee of the International Symposium on Poliomyelitis Control, sponsored by the National Institutes of Health Fogarty International Center. She served a term as president of the Infectious Diseases Society of America (1974/1975), and the Yale School of Medicine created an annual Dorothy M. Horstmann Lectureship as a continuing tribute. Horstmann died on January 18, 2001.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series consists generally of correspondence with or about colleagues, institutions, publishers, periodicals, organizations, conferences, and committees. The files are arranged in alphabetical order.

The correspondence includes exchanges with or about several professional colleagues whom Horstmann also considered personal friends. Among these are I. George Miller, James Henderson, Sunderland Gear, Herdis von Magnus, José Madalengoitia, Jeremy Morris, and Gertrude Van Wagenen. Some of Horstmann's correspondence with Albert Sabin is filed in this series but their exchanges that concern the sharing results and specimens are filed in Series IV. There are almost no surviving personal family letters.

Yale University files document women's issues at Yale, particularly in the 1970s. Files for the Yale University Committee on the Status of Women (also known as the Greene Committee), the Advisory Committee on the Education of Women, and the Yale Academic and Professional Women's forum contain discussions of contemporary concerns over women in research, the promotional ladder for women, maternity leave, child care, and discrimination.

Horstmann's large number of John Rodman Paul files attests to the special working relationship between the two. The files detail their collaboration in research and publication. The Paul materials also include correspondence concerning publication of a festschrift in his honor and letters of sympathy at his death.

Horstmann expressed some of her political convictions in letters to congressmen. These letters are filed in the section for United States Congress. Prominent among these are letters concerning the political situation in southern Africa.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Arranged chronologically, the series includes Horstmann's unpublished lectures and correspondence concerning publications. Though Horstmann contributed well over 150 professional papers, these, being published, are not in the files.

The lecture files rarely contain word for word typescripts of her talks. Rather, one finds in them hand written outlines on paper or index cards in Horstmann's large round penmanship. Some lecture notes served for more than one appearance, as can occasionally be noticed from the numbering of the pages. Because Horstmann gave so many talks on rubella and poliomyelitis, those topics appear often.
A comprehensive bibliography of Horstmann's published work is in Series VI.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series consists of a small number of teaching files from courses Horstmann taught at Yale in the Department of Epidemiology and Public Health, the School of Medicine, and other university venues, as well as courses taught outside of Yale. The files are arranged by course title under a heading for each department or school in which she taught and include notes made in preparing for the course, outlines, course descriptions, instructors guides, charts, and bibliographies. In no case are all the lectures for an individual course available.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains extensive notes, data, and reports generated by Horstmann's work in the laboratory at Yale and during field studies around the world. The series contains notebooks, data sheets, and reports of projects. The materials are organized in three sections: Research notes on viruses, Field studies, and Administrative files.

The files in the section Research notes on viruses reflect Horstmann's major research interests in poliomyletis and rubella. These files are arranged in chronological order within three headings: Poliomyelitis studies, Rubella studies, and Other.

The Field studies files also document her research interests in polio and rubella and show the range of her travels to assure the safety and effectiveness of vaccination programs. The section is arranged alphabetically by geographical locality. Many of the field studies resulted from an invitation to Horstmann to investigate problems or to improve the health situation in a given area. Because the field studies include analyses done on site as well as the research done on collected samples shipped to the Yale laboratories, the results cover a longer period of time than the actual visit. File names are those given by Horstmann.

There are numerous files for field studies conducted at the Southbury Training School in Connecticut. Residents were used for epidemiological research on poliomyelitis and rubella vaccines and antibodies. Since the school provided a stable, isolated population of retarded children, researchers could follow results over an extended period of time.

Similarly, there are extensive files from studies done in Cairo, Egypt. This research built on studies and relationships begun by John Rodman Paul in the 1940s when he was Director of the Virus Commission of the United States Army Epidemiological Board. Horstmann continued the work in 1955 under the auspices of Navy Medical Research (NAMRU #3), where she also assisted in the development of their tissue culture laboratory. She studied types and distribution of poliomyelitis viruses collected from non-paralytic cases as well as orphan viruses (those not associated with a specific disease).

The field studies also include a few surveys conducted by epidemiology and public health students taking the core course EPH 510, for example, a study of Hamden High School first year students' immunity to rubella and a survey of the immune status of adolescents in Danbury.
The small amount of Administrative files include miscellaneous reports, research grant material, and a folder regarding animal care.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Arranged chronologically, the series documents Horstmann's interest and involvement in relevant professional meetings both in the United States and abroad. The files include programs, correspondence, agendas and handouts. If the papers contain the text of lecture Horstmann gave at a meeting, that text is included in the Series II, Writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains a small quantity of Dorothy Horstmann's personal materials. These include tributes and honors, memorabilia, and a smattering of travel notes from her extensive world travels. Materials in the series are arranged in alphabetical order by record type.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series includes portraits of Horstmann, as well as photographs of her colleagues. Those of colleagues include pictures at professional meetings, as well as the annual Yale School of Medicine faculty photographs. The series also includes photographs from Horstmann's travels. These are arranged by place, under the heading Trips.
